newsitem.title: USA: The Hartford drops ITT name on spinoff anniversary.
newsitem.headline: The Hartford drops ITT name on spinoff anniversary.

text.p: ITT Hartford, whose name had caused confusion since its spinoff from ITT Corp. last year, said Thursday it was changing its name to "The Hartford" on the anniversary of its listing as an independent company.
The change is to become effective immediately as the company's brand name, but shareholders will be asked to vote on the firm's legal name in May of next year.
"During this first year, we have firmly established ourselves as a dynamic, international financial services company," Donald Frahm, The Hartford's chairman and chief executive said in a statement.
The company's stock price has risen by 35 percent since it ended its 25-year marriage to ITT Corp. on December 20 of last year, Frahm said.
The 186-year-old company has also realigned itself into five core businesses to position itself for growth, he added.
The nation's third-oldest insurer said that its research this year showed that the market and consumers were confused about who owned the company.
"The Hartford and the stag have a strong brand identity," said Connie Gurney, spokeswoman for The Hartford.
"We're already widely known as The Hartford, and we're trying to capitalize on it and strengthen the brand."
As part of the image makeover, the company will launch a $10-12 million ad campaign created by Boston agency Arnold Communications early next year, said Gurney.
The name change will not affect foreign subsidiaries of The Hartford.
The Hartford is the nation's seventh-biggest property-casualty insurer and eight-biggest life insurance group. It had assets of $104 billion as of end September.
